Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC Phase II: Center for the Integration of Composites into Infrastructure (CICI)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Efficient infrastructure systems such as highways, bridges, buildings, pipelines, flood control systems and utilities are all necessary for a healthy economy and comfortable standard of living. Concrete, steel and timber are the backbones of physical infrastructure. High strength polymer composites have been used for aerospace structures for about five decades and their use in civil infrastructure spans about 20 years. To accelerate the adoption of polymer composites into infrastructure, the NSF I/UCRC Center of the Integration of Composites into Infrastructure (CICI) was established as a joint effort of West Virginia University (WVU), North Carolina State University (NCSU) and the University of Miami. Recently, NSF has awarded a travel grant to establish an additional CICI site at Nanjing University of Technology in China. The NSF I/UCRC program brings together universities, private companies and government agencies together to leverage the research dollars for all parties by engaging in highly cooperative research. CICI's work with civil infrastructure has a tremendous effect on daily life, thus the Nation as a whole benefits as composite and hybrid materials lead to infrastructure systems of higher safety, shorter construction times and longer life spans at a reduced overall cost and improved labor productivity with the creation of new and higher skilled job opportunities. Member companies and end users benefit from the interaction with others in their field including highly trained students, with over 100 students expected to pass through CICI in the next 5 years. CICI is prolific technology transfer machine, exceeding the output for most I/UCRCs through the publishing of journal articles and conference presentations to promote the scientific research and knowledge dissemination.

Broadly speaking, the technical focus of CICI can be broken into four different areas. Initially, fundamental research projects are undertaken to broaden the knowledge base on infrastructure composites. This includes lifecycle performance, aging studies, evaluation of bond strength within a composite and as a substrate, and many others. From this on-going research, products are being developed that can be mass-implemented in infrastructure markets, including innovative hollow core or basalt fiber FRP rebar, waterway products that are noncorrosive or fabric reinforced cementitious composites for masonry wall strengthening and many others. The implementation of these products is the next focus area and is primarily accomplished through the development of codes and specifications. CICI has worked on the ASCE LRFD pultruded GFRP composites code, ASTM specifications, ACI building design and construction codes, the International Code Council and IIFC. Finally, CICI has an evaluation component based on IAB member feedback to ensure the composites that are implemented in the field are performing as designed as a part of our long-term performance program. Thus, through research, development, implementation and evaluation, CICI is involved in all facets of composite product evolution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the five-year duration of Phase II of this award, the major goal of the University of Miami (UM) site was to lead and coordinate research and development (R&D) efforts of high interest to industry partners with focus on:  a) composites as internal reinforcement to concrete; and, b) composites externally bonded to concrete members for strength and ductility enhancement. For the latter, both polymeric and cementitious-based (inorganic) matrices were of interest. The acronym FRP (fiber-reinforced polymer) is used to identify the class of composites covered in this project.

New Construction

The demand for the development of a more efficient and durable transportation infrastructure is among the priorities of highway authorities worldwide.  In the United States, the economic impact of steel corrosion in concrete highway bridges is estimated to exceed 15% of total annual costs. FRP bars are a suitable replacement for steel rebars as concrete reinforcement in structures subject to aggressive environments. In addition to center partners, UM worked with state Departments of Transportation (DOTs) and other infrastructure owners for the demonstration and deployment of new technology. This included the development of guides and standards with national and international code-writing agencies.

Repair and Strengthening

UM focused on composites with both organic and inorganic matrices. In addition to FRP, the acronyms for the composites investigated at UM were SRP for ?steel reinforced polymer,? FRCM for ?fabric reinforced cementitious matrix,? and SRG for ?steel reinforced grout.?

In the areas of SRP and SRG, UM has been the main institution in the nation to conduct this type of research work. In conjunction with industry, UM has also provided the leadership required in the development of pre-standards issued by the International Code Council - Evaluation Service (ICC-ES). These pre-standards are known as ?Acceptance Criteria? and provide the requirements that a new technology must satisfy in order to show compliance with building code provisions.

Deployment

Two pedestrian bridges using FRP internal reinforcement (i.e., Fate Bridge and Innovation Bridge) were constructed at UM. For the latter, only concrete elements solely reinforced and prestressed with FRP composites were used. The concrete reinforcement featured unique configurations such as Basalt FRP continuous closed stirrups used in the pier-caps and curbs as well as prefabricated Basalt FRP cages for the auger-cast foundation piles. The main load-carrying members of the bridge were two double-tee concrete girders prestressed with carbon FRP tendons. Elements of the bridge were instrumented with vibrating-wire gauges to monitor performance over time. During two load tests conducted at the precast yard and on the completed structure, performance was evaluated and successfully confirmed. In addition to strain data, periodic deflection measurements have shown field performance of the bridge to be in accordance with the predicted behavior.

UM supported the Florida DOT for the design of the replacement bridge (Halls River Bridge) constructed in Citrus County, FL. This is the first in the nation, vehicular, five-span bridge that did not use steel as reinforcement for any concrete elements of the structure. In particular, one PhD student was deployed to the construction site for one year to provide assistance and expertise to the contractor while collecting performance and constructability data.

UM is currently contributing to the construction of a residential building in the Bahamas and a marine dock (completed) in Miami. In addition to FRP reinforcement, both structures include the use of a concrete mixture using seawater as replacement for fresh water.

Dissemination

Research and implementation results have been disseminate via technical publications, presentation in national and international conferences and development of design guides and standards.

As an example of contribution to the technical literature of the American Association of State Highway Transportation Officials (AASHTO), UM developed a revised design guide on behalf of AASHTO Committee T6 to allow for the use of glass FRP bars in both the superstructure and substructure of bridges. The guide was published in December 2018 with the title: "AASHTO LRFD Bridge Design Guide Specifications for GFRP Reinforced Concrete ? 2nd Edition."

Several workshops were organized during the course of the project duration. For example, in November 2015, a workshop was held to present to the Spanish-speaking technical communities of Latin America and Florida the current guides for design and construction of externally bonded FRP systems. The workshop was concluded with a visit to UM laboratory facilities and exhibits from FRP suppliers, contractors and designers. Similarly, in May 2017, a two-day workshop was co-organized to discuss the outcomes of a current research on sustainable concrete using seawater, salt-contaminated aggregates, and non-corrosive reinforcement followed by an update on the construction and site visit to the Halls River Bridge.
